title: Chateau d'Yquem Sauternes 2019 (Half Bottle 375mL)
description: Small bottles for big evenings right here. Bring home THE KING of Sauternes, and you'll rule the conversation and food pairings. No need to wax poetic here; this wine is incredible (just read the reviews). Only two cases were imported at this fantastic price.
summary: The history of Château d’Yquem is like a novel, an epic saga full of events and colourful personalities spanning more than four centuries. Chateau d’Yquem is not only the most famous chateau in Sauternes today, the estate has possessed an exalted reputation dating back to the middle ages when d’Yquem was owned by the King of England. Today the estate is owned by the infamous luxury brand Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton who have made significant re-investment into the property. Yquem is in a class of their own, quite literally, in the classification of 1855, it was given a unique classification of Premier Cru Superieur", because it so clearly stood above all other Chateau.

title: Bibi Graetz Testamatta Toscana 2018 OWC (Methuselah 6L)
description:
Over the years, we’ve been lucky to sell a bit of Testamatta, but magnums are a first, especially at this fine price. I’m guessing most of you savvy oenophiles need no introduction to Bibi’s wines, but there's a huge raft of scores and info below if you need a refresher! PERFECTION in magnums...we’re just stunned!

100% sangiovese, of course, as always, 50+ year old vines, made at his medieval castle, Castello di Vincigliata overlooking Florence. Bibi is an icon, self-taught and one of the early “cult” winemakers in Tuscany. He has a reputation of being Italy’s most talented and interesting winemakers. The labels are all personally drawn by Bibi Graetz, with the help from his daughter who both come from a long line of talented visual artists. Bibi is able to combine both of his passions into an amazing masterpiece. The wine in this vintage is five stars with wine publications predicting that this vintage will fall between the lavish 2015s and extravagant 2016s. Don't miss

PAIRING IDEAS: Try something more traditionally Florentine. Did you know they do crepes in Tuscany? Yup – check this out – crespelle alla Fiorentina. Hard to go wrong with ricotta and bechamel, are we right? Here’s a recipe.

MUSIC SUGGESTIONS: Checked out the new Eddie Vedder album yet? "Earthling" is growing on us, check it out. The opening track "Invincible" is a great vibe for some world-class sangiovese!
summary: "Testa-Matta" in Italy is someone with a strong personality, a distinctive style and positive attitude and creativity. No other name could describe better Bibi Graetz flagship wine. A Super Tuscan made with 100% Sangiovese from old vines, this wine is the result of the combination of tradition and creativity, elevating the idea of Tuscan Sangiovese and bringing the word "Supertuscan" to the next level. From a medieval castle, Castello di Vincigliata, acquired by his parents over 60 years ago, winemaker Bibi Graetz crafts his wines on a hillside overlooking the great city of Florence. Beginning initially with only a small, 5-acre vineyard on this hillside in Fiesole, in little under two decades, Bibi has become one of Italy's most ingenious winemakers adding "cult winemaker" in addition to "talented abstract artist" to his dossier.

title: Bibi Graetz Colore 20 Anniversario Toscana 2019
description:
Bibi Graetz is the hottest producer in Tuscany, with his “Testamatta” bottling turning the Tuscan wine biz upside down soon after the first release in the early 2000s. Now, enter “Colore” – his flagship wine taken from the very best barrels and his oldest, highest elevation vines. This 100% sangiovese is a must for any serious Italian wine collector!

The 2019 vintage marks the 20th anniversary of Bibi Graetz winery. What a couple of decades! Countless 95-100 point scores and a reputation that went almost immediately to rising star and is now approaching all-time legendary status. His impact on Italian wine has been staggering, and we’re just thrilled to have stumbled upon these wines some years back. His winery sits on the hill of Fiesole, overlooking the verdant, rolling foothills of Florence in the heart of Tuscany. From the very beginning, his goal was to acquire some of the oldest vineyards in Tuscany, with a focus on the ancient, local varietals, Sangiovese being chief amongst those, but also including Canaiolo and Colorino.

“Colore” is the highest expression of his dream, from very old vineyards of Sangiovese that are 70, 80, or even 90 years old. Fruit from three separate vineyards – Lamole, Vincigliata, and Siena – is the basis of this blend, though only the best barrels make the final bottling. Set on porous soils of sand mixed with stone, these high-altitude vines are hand-harvested, with up to eight passes through each vineyard, pulling only those clusters that are perfectly ripe. The fruit is sorted again at the winery before undergoing spontaneous fermentations in old, open-top barriques. The grapes are punched down by hand 6-8 times each day during fermentation before transferring to new barriques where they’ll finish secondary fermentation as they age for the next 20 months.

The 2019 vintage was a remarkable one for the region, and Bibi had this to say about the conditions, “Monumental, there is no better word to describe this vintage. Roundness in every single aspect of the wine: elegance, freshness and great acidity that gives very fine layers, surprisingly detectable on the nose and at the first sip. Colore 2019 celebrates my 20th anniversary as a winemaker. It has been a great journey since 2000, full of satisfactions and now with this vintage I finally close the circle. My wines at the beginning were looking for structure and concentration, in 2009 I realized that “elegance” should have been the main drive. In 2019 I did it!”

Can’t disagree in the slightest. This effort is powerful, taut, and exceptionally structured – elegance is interwoven throughout, but make no mistake, this is ample, layered, and even intimidating in its youthful exuberance. This is a wine to be treasured, and any patience shown will be rewarded threefold over the years to come. Classic cherries, berries, and red currants, with tinges of blood orange, spearmint oil, toasted fennel seed, savory balsam herbs, and camphor. This is serious stuff that will only get even better as time marches on. We only have 7 cases…do what you must and grab a few of these for your collection! While they last!

PAIRING IDEAS: When the time comes, make this classic, super easy, Tuscan dish: Spaghetti con Salsiccia e Cavolo Nero – the bitterness of the kale, the richness of the Italian sausage, the spice of the fried garlic… it all just works so beautifully.

MUSIC SUGGESTIONS: What else but Pink Floyd’s “Time” … patience is required on this beauty, but don’t let the years pass you by without enjoying a great wine like this either!

Beginning initially with only a small, 5-acre vineyard on this hillside in Fiesole, in little under two decades, Bibi has become one of Italy's most ingenious winemakers adding "cult winemaker" in addition to "talented abstract artist" to his dossier.

variants.title: Bibi Graetz Colore 20 Anniversario Toscana 2019

title: Clos Saint Antonin Cotes du Rhone Villages Plan de Dieu 2020
description:
Made by the Sabon family of Châteauneuf du Pape’s revered Domaine de la Janasse, Clos Saint Antonin is a new project from their estate to the north, across the river from Gigondas. From old vines in the village of Plan de Dieu, this wine drinks like Châteauneuf’s richer cousin. At NEARLY 60% OFF, this is a new find that every CdP lover needs to try!

Seriously, $18.95 for a “Baby Châteauneuf” that Jeb Dunnuck says “will give many a Châteauneuf du Pape a run for its money”... are we for real?!?! You bet. This is a classic southern Rhone blend – roughly 50% grenache, 30% mourvedre, and 20% syrah from 50+-year-old vines in iron-rich clay soils littered with the region's famous “rolled pebble” stones. The varieties are harvested and fermented separately, with the grenache aged in large oak foudres while the syrah and mourvedre spend their time in neutral barriques.

The style of this wine is unapologetically hedonistic, with rich, dark, and ripe fruit notes of blackberries, black plums, and mulberries. The fruits are punctuated with ample spice notes of garrigue, black pepper, and clove – uplifted by a mineral edge and delicately floral tones. This has the structure and weight to survive another 5-7 years beautifully, but for pure, unbridled pleasure…it’s drinking quite well in the here and now! Delightfully complex and richly pleasing wine, even at the full retail of $45…but at 58% OFF, this is a tremendous wine to have in quantity. While it lasts!
summary:
Clos Saint Antonin is a 15 hectare estate located outside the town of Jonquières within the Côtes-du-Rhône Village of Plan de Dieu. A short drive away from Courthézon where Domaine de la Janasse is situated, Clos Saint Antonin was purchased by the Sabon family in 2014. Small, compact and contiguous estates rarely come on the market in the Rhône, let alone ones planted on the classic red clays, galets and sand typical of Plan de Dieu. While it is quite common to see the famed estates of Châteauneuf-du-Pape looking over the Rhône river towards Lirac to expand their holdings, more and more are looking north to Plan de Dieu since this terroir is quite similar to what they find in their backyard. While the whole family is involved with its farming and winemaking, Isabelle Sabon is heading up this new project – one supplemented by some of her family’s vineyards in Le Crau for the Clos Saint Antonin Châteauneuf-du-Pape.

St Antonin is the name of the 18th century Provençale Mas that stands in the center of the property a name that has been used in documents dating back to the time of Napoleon. Isabelle makes four wines at her estate: a IGP Principauté d’Orange from Clairette, Chardonnay & Bourboulenc, a Côtes-du-Rhône from younger vines of Grenache, Syrah & Mourvèdre, a Côtes-du-Rhône Villages Plan de Dieu from older vines of Grenache, Mourvèdre & Syrah, and a Châteauneuf-du-Pape from old vines of Grenache located in La Fond du Loup and Le Crau. The grapes for these cuvées are farmed organically and harvested by hand then partially destemmed and fermented by natural yeasts at Domaine de la Janasse. Aging is in concrete tanks, foudres and neutral French oak demi-muids.

title: Terroir Al Limit Priorat Les Tosses 2017
description:
This is just for you, our very select tip-top best First Bottlers. 100 point Priorat…don’t see that every day, do ya? This is an infinitesimally small, 225 case total production, 100% carignan, 80+-year-old vines, high elevation, black slate soils, from the heart of the Torroja del Priorat…seriously cool stuff, through and through. Only about 4 cases are available, and this is one that can’t be missed!!!

Dominik Huber has created something truly magical in the high-altitude, barren landscape of Torroja del Priorat. Starting as a project with Eben Sadie, who makes perhaps the very best South African wines under his Sadie Family label, Dominik has turned out a portfolio of fantastic wines that would make any estate in the world envious. In 2021 alone, Terroir al Limit has turned out 5 distinct wines that all received 95+ point scores from Wine Advocate! He’s a phenom that is changing the game in Priorat, one of Spain’s most historic and long-standing regions. His focus on a varietal-dominant carignan wine is rare for the region, but he has harnessed the complexity and power of this site to create a singular wine that just simply must be tasted to be believed.

Grown at some 2000 feet above sea level, in the arid, hot hillsides of Priorat, overlooking the Mediterranean port of Tarragona in the Northeast of Spain, this vineyard belongs to another time. The Catalonian village is ancient, with clay roofs, closely set buildings of earthen stone, and cobblestone streets. Cooling breezes that bring in moisture from the sea act as a moderating influence, allowing these 72-year-old vines to produce small amounts of highly concentrated fruit. Over the years, Dominik has limited the use of oak, both for fermentation and aging, and going forward (as of 2020) the winery’s red wines will be fermented and aged entirely in concrete vats. For this 2017 vintage, 70% of the wine was aged in large neutral oak foudres, with 30% in concrete. This is a mysterious beauty to drink, a wine so layered, so dichotomous, so uniquely pleasing that I’m having trouble selecting the dominant characteristics… is it the black cherry? The licorice and lavender pastilles? Mushroom tea and roasted herbs? Blueberries and violets? It’s all there, and so much more, just waiting to be experienced by the bold, the wise, and the undaunted. Double 96s, 97, 100...the critics have spoken. If pressed, I’m going with a 99, because just like the Great One, the stats, the presence, the total package – it is all just impossible to properly quantify – but no one, anywhere, questions the greatness. While it lasts!
summary: When Eben Sadie and Dominik Huber first met in 2001 at Mas Martinet, Eben was a promising and highly-regarded young enologist from South Africa and Dominik, German by birth, was a wine enthusiast with a background in business administration and an interest in the culinary arts. In short order they became fast friends. With the help of the Perez family of Mas Martinet, Eben and Dominik purchased some fruit and leased a little corner in the cellar of Cims de Porrera where they vinified their first vintage of Dits del Terra in 2001. After two years at Cims de Porrera they moved into a tiny cellar in Torroja del Priorat. The move coincided with the first vintage of Arbossar in 2003. In the following years they released additional cuvees: Torroja in 2005, Manyes and Tosses in 2006, Pedra de Guix in 2008 and Terra de Cuques in 2011. Throughout the decade since its founding, Terroir al Limit has evolved in its understanding of the Priorat - coming to view it as a region similar to Burgundy in its complexity and potential to produce elegant and transparent wines.

title: Casa Castillo Las Gravas Jumilla 2020
description:
Jumilla is a relatively obscure Spanish region despite its long history. Casa Castillo is primed to change that, as they continually make some of the highest quality for value vines in the world. Following a slew of great scores (every Las Gravas since 2012 has scored 94 or higher with Robert Parker’s Wine Advocate), they have exploded with this 98 POINT beauty!

“Considered by many observers to be the finest estate in Jumilla, Casa Castillo is a treasure-trove for fabulous values, particularly from the Monastrell (Mourvedre) grape that loves the chalky terroirs and cool slopes of the Sierra del Molar.” - Robert Parker, Jr.

Yes, indeed. José Maria Vicente is a third-generation owner and operator of Casa Castillo, a farm that began as a rosemary plantation but has evolved into the preeminent estate in the DO of Jumilla. The winery and vineyards came to the Vicente family in 1941, though the estate didn’t begin producing its own label until fifty years later. This is a long-time Wine Advocate favorite, and we absolutely loved the 2015 vintage we offered a few years back. This is ASTOUNDINGLY DELICIOUS at any price – at our best-in-the-states price… you simply HAVE to taste it!

The family’s vineyard holding became certified organic in 2019, but their 2020 vintage is without question the finest they’ve produced since they began over 30 years ago. 92% monastrell (the local name for mourvedre), rounded out with 8% garnacha (grenache) – this is a bold, bright-flavored wine with perfumed and floral aromatics, leading to earthy, resinous notes of pine needles, and dried ceps. The palate abounds with red cherries, chipped rocks, pink peppercorns, and creamy oak sensations. Reminiscent of a highly polished Bandol, there is a vein of purity here where weight and textures are lifted up – creating a full wine that nevertheless floats effortlessly across the palate. Just a monumental effort that needs to be experienced to be believed.

Get in on this producer now while you can. They are already on the rise, and their prices are sure to go the way of top-flight Toros and Riojas before long! A cool $30 off for this 98 POINT stunner? Not to be missed.
summary: Well-trodden paths like Highway 29 in Napa, RN74 in Burgundy or the Mosel River in Germany are obvious vinous routes that have been signposted and gentrified over decades but not Jumilla. Parched, bleak and seemingly barren under the heat of midsummer there are only the faintest hints of civilization, usually in the form of an isolated sign, a decaying old farm house or the random fellow traveler rushing to get out of the sun. Jumilla is about roughing it, about getting to know farmers and their families and if you’re lucky being invited into their homes to share a meal. It’s a place worth getting lost in. If you’ve played your cards right, the person inviting you to Jumilla is José Maria Vicente. José Maria is a third generation owner and operator of Casa Castillo a farm that began as a rosemary plantation but one that has evolved into the preeminent estate in the DO of Jumilla. While the smell of rosemary still lingers in the air, the pale, rocky soils surrounding his house and cellar are now planted with vines and almond orchards. When José Maria’s grandfather purchased Casa Castillo in 1941 there was already a winery, cellar and some scattered vineyards on the property dating to the 1870s, established by French refugees fleeing the plight of phylloxera in their native land. In 1985 José and his father began to replant the vineyards and expand them with the goal of making wine on the property. In 1991 they bottled their first commercial vintage.

title: Hartwell Cabernet Sauvignon T5 2013
description:
Truly a rarity. If you know, YOU KNOW, but honestly…? Most people don’t. The fruit is grown from the highest point on the Hartwell estate and aged for two years in prized Taransaud T5 barrels. Cabernet collectors...this hits EVERY SINGLE sweet spot today. A MUST at our price. T5 is in the heart of the Stags Leap District, sourced from the highest point on the Hartwell estate, overlooking what is now Realm winery. Ultra-fine, polished, sexy juice, with an enormous aging curve – the wine is truly blockbuster - packed to the gills with extract, concentration, and turned-up-to-100 flavors and mouthfeel.

Let’s talk about a true rockstar winemaker, as well - Benoit Touquette. He is the Frenchman, student of Michel Rolland (who also consults at Hartwell and Realm), and too-many-huge-scores-to-count winemaker here, besides his epically collectible other wines such as Realm, Kata, Fait-Main and more.

Lastly, besides the incredible rarity of this bottling (and our eye-popping price), 2013 is a FANTASTIC vintage in the Valley. Now with a few years of age on it, it has grown into itself and drinking fabulously. Here’s a few of the pros on the vintage:

"...the finest vintage for Bordeaux varietals I've ever tasted in my 37 years of experience in Napa Valley..." - Robert Parker, Jr.

"The 2013s are majestic wines of the very highest level..." - Antonio Galloni

"...one of the most epic and awesome vintages the North Coast of California has ever produced, especially for Bordeaux varieties..." - Robert Parker, Jr.

NOT a cab for the shy, but definitely for those looking for something TRULY special and unique! We have a TINY, tiny amount to offer -- first come, first served!

PAIRING IDEAS: This wine is SO big and brawny, we’re going to go with LAMB. Grind some for a killer burger (with a bit of tzatziki sauce), or ideally, grill up a leg of lamb you’ve slathered with herbs and garlic and red wine and EVOO, grilled and smoked on your Weber. Yum.

MUSIC SUGGESTIONS: Rock out. “The Descent” by Bob Mould from the excellent Silver Age album sounds amazing up LOUD.
summary: Hartwell vineyards were founded in 1986 when Bob Hartwell purchased 90 acres of Wappo Hill in the Stags Leap District of Napa Valley. Their inaugural vintage was in 1990 that sold out immediately and they have since established their reputation for fine Cabernet Sauvignon. The estate is now owned by Realm Cellars principals Beonoit Touquette, Juan Mercado and Scott Becker with consulting work by Michel Rolland.

title: Louis Jadot Beaune 150th Anniversay Premier Cru 2009
description:
We were one of the very first “online” retailers in the USA to sell this wine back in the day when it was first offered (2009), and we still rock it every year it is made. A terrific Premier Cru bottling that encompasses 17 of the 1ers within Beaune, it was first created in the ‘09 vintage to commemorate the winery’s 150th anniversary and is still made in very good years. No surprise, it is a blockbuster. If you haven’t bought any 2015 red Burgundy, this is one not to miss. If you have already, this can serve as a cellar staple and makes an excellent centerpiece for your own Burgundy-drinking adventures for years to come!

The contrast between the writeups for this wine from Decanter (96) and Vinous (93+) is striking, although both of them rave about it, and rightly so -- you can read them below. We, of course, had to open some to drink ourselves, because...Burgundy! Never miss an opportunity. Our notes: Floral. Beautiful color. Apple, cinnamon, juicy plum, a whiff of oak. Great structure, wonderful density and texture, SUPER-long, complex, finish. We're leaning quite a bit more to the Decanter side of things, although this is clearly a BABY and will improve for many years. Wonderful -- esp. at our PRICE!

First come, first served!
summary: Three decades. That’s the time it took Louis Henry Denis Jadot to found our house, in 1859, and to lay the foundations of a family-owned domaine. He would contribute to the renown of the wines of Burgundy by developing a negociant business focused on selling the wines in Northern European markets. His descendants followed in his footsteps at the head of the family business.

title: Paradigm Cabernet Sauvignon Oakville 2015
description:
One of our all-time fave Cabs from the legendary Heidi Barrett!! A FANTASTIC, no-brainer bargain relative to so many other Napa Cabs and arguably the finest in a decade or more! A Napa Valley classic since the late 80s!!

Did you know this is Heidi Barrett's only continuous client since they began? From her Screaming Eagle days to her current mega-stardom, she has always made this wine in a much more "classic" style that I utterly love. Less super-oak, some structure, medium-weight, terrific balance...and they age gorgeously (drink the 1994 now, it's killer). A huge must-have every year, in my book.

$79.95. Do you even know what a ridonkulously fair price this is? I urge, I insist, I PLEAD that if you love classically structured Napa Cabs (I want you to evoke things like Dunn, Heitz, Mayacamas, old Phelps wines and so on) --- this is a MUST-BUY. 2015 to boot, which has an amazing ripe fruit profile that will drink well early but will also cellar like a champ! A fantastic vintage! Trust your wizened old, grizzly-bearded, cantankerous wine merchant! This wine is KILLING it!
summary: Owned and managed by Ren and Marilyn Harris, two winegrowers with extraordinarily deep roots in Napa Valley. Marilyn's grandparents immigrated from Italy to Napa Valley in 1890, while Ren's family came to California in 1769. Marilyn and Ren moved to Napa Valley in the 1960's and settled into their home just east of where Paradigm sits today. Paradigm consists of four contiguous parcels totaling fifty acres in the heart of Oakville. Heidi Barrett is the consulting winemaker and in today's Napa Cab marketplace, this remains one of the finest values that we know of.

title: Anselmann Trockenbeerenauslese Ortega 2015 (Half Bottle 375mL)
description:
It’s not often we get an opportunity on one of the rarest, most coveted, late-harvest wines to be had in the world today! Trockenbeerenauslese from Pfalz in the southwest of Germany! Just in time for the holidays, this is an incredibly delicious dessert wine – at a fraction of the cost, these wines typically fetch!

Alright, let’s start with a little info, for those not familiar with this rare creature… “Trockenbeerenauslese” translates to "dry berry selection" – a reference to the German classification system based on the ripeness level and sugar content of the grapes. This sweet dessert wine is made from individually selected, botrytis-affected grapes that have the highest sugar levels possible. The grapes are all hand-picked, oftentimes berry by berry, in a painstakingly difficult process, before fermenting. The grapes are almost fully desiccated at the time of harvest, with extremely concentrated sugars and flavors that make these wines so special. Trockenbeerenauslese wines rank among the greatest sweet wines in the world alongside Royal Tokaji and Sauternes, yet because German wines come in at every sweetness level across the spectrum, these extremely late-harvest wines are perhaps rarer here than anywhere else in the world!

And yet, while this wine is undoubtedly sweet… it is also so much more than just that! Intense acidity cuts any possibility of the wine coming across as cloying, and the mineral/herbal notes add complexity to the myriad fruit flavors of peaches, honeyed apricots, and orange marmalade. The viscous, creamy weight of the wine makes for a sip that goes on forever, with deeply rich and intense flavors exploding across all facets of your palate.

The Anselmann family has been consistently growing grapes and making wines in the region over the last 450 years… and there are even documents that show the family’s ownership of vineyards as far back as 1126! They’re an iconic Rhineland producer that has produced every type of wine grape conceivable for Germany, with 150 hectares planted to traditional varieties like riesling and pinot noir (spatburgunder) as well as uncommon grapes such as tempranillo, solaris, cabernet blanc, and this grape, ortega. Ortega is a cross created in 1948 by pairing müller-thurgau with scheurebe grapes, creating a frost-resistant berry that is prized for its stone fruit aromatics, high sugar potential, and relatively early ripening. All this is extremely important for the site and style of this wine, and the result is nothing short of spectacular! Words simply cannot do it justice… this is a wine that needs to be tasted! Luckily, at our fantastic price, you can do so, all without having to hop on a plane to Frankfurt! While it lasts!
summary: The Anselmann Family, located in the southern Palatinate area of Pfalz, Germany, has been associated with viticulture and fine wine for more than 450 years. Its wines have received high praise for their outstanding quality, readily drinkable upon-release style, and traditional winemaking techniques. These sweet wines will change the way you think about post-dinner wines. Let this bottling mix up your usual dessert and make the dinner conversation run wild with excitement.

title: Luigi Pira Barolo Margheria 2018
description:
“One of Piedmont’s superstars… these are wines of extraordinary complexity and breathtaking richness.” - Robert Parker, Jr.

Yep, no argument there. Luigi Pira is a consistent favorite producer in Serralunga d’ Alba, situated at the very heart of Barolo. This single cru bottling, Margheria, is one of three cru Pira holdings in Serralunga and stands as the oldest cru in the portfolio. Set on 1.5 hectares of calcareous clay soils, these vines average 50 years of age, with some of the original plantings for the vineyard that goes back to 1959. The site is known for its elegance, minerality, and ageability of the wines produced there – and this wine excels in all three of those categories. 95 points to start, with other top critics' scores soon to follow, this beauty isn’t likely to be around for long!

This is one for the ages – intensely flavored and wonderfully floral, with earthy and sweet notes of dried cherries and roses, new leather, and fresh hay leading into an immensely long finish layered with saline edges and iron ore. So ethereally complex, supremely elegant, and undoubtedly delicious! At this price, I’m getting six...one to open every three years!

Like so many highly collectible producers in the Barolo (especially Serralunga!), in the early part of the 20th century, Pira’s top grapes were sold to other producers, such as Gaja and others, for decades. In the early 90s, Gianpaolo, Luigi's son, started to take part in the winery management, and wine quality became the key factor. More of the best fruit was kept in-house and the prestige of this small producer grew and grew. Today, Gianpaolo runs the winemaking, and his brothers, Romolo and Claudio, focus on tending the vineyards. A true family affair with a bright and illustrious history to come, this is a remarkable deal on cru Barolo from a top producer. While it lasts!
summary: In the 1950s Luigi Pira decided to focus on grapes and wine, and in the following decades, he sold grapes and open wine to the biggest wineries in the area of Alba, which sought after high quality products from Serralunga d'Alba. It was a first step towards its own production. In the early 90s, Gianpaolo, Luigi's son, started to take part in the winery management, and the wine quality became the key factor. Today, Gianpaolo is flanked by his brothers Romolo and Claudio. Vignarionda is considered a grand cru vineyard of Serralunga d'Alba.

title: Domaine Laporte Sancerre Le Rochoy 2021
summary:
For several generations, Domaine Laporte has occupied a pioneering position and acquired a reputation for the quality of its wines. This notoriety is the fruit of the rigor, the determination and the know-how of two passionate Sancerre families who have succeeded each other at its helm.
"La Comtesse", located on the Kimmeridgian marls of the famous hillside "Les Monts Damnés" in Chavignol. This wine will stun you with its vibrance, vigor, and tension. Outstanding!

seo.description:
For several generations, Domaine Laporte has occupied a pioneering position and acquired a reputation for the quality of its wines. This notoriety is the fruit of the rigor, the determination and the know-how of two passionate Sancerre families who have succeeded each other at its helm.
"La Comtesse", located on the Kimmeridgian marls of the famous hillside "Les Monts Damnés" in Chavignol. This wine will stun you with its vibrance, vigor, and tension. Outstanding!

variants.title: Domaine Laporte Sancerre Le Rochoy 2021

title: Champagne Gallimard Cuvee Prestige Les Riceys 2015
description:
Gallimard just makes us proud. We discovered them some years back, when they were completely unknown outside of France, and started importing as much as they would give us. The wines have just gotten better and better every year, and now, the world is taking note. These are grower-producers of the first order, pushing the envelope in the Cote de Bars and changing the game of pinot noir-based Champagnes! Nearly HALF OFF...UNDER $35?!?! Just remarkable stuff.

Didier and Arnaud make the perfect father-son team. Didier is the old guard, rooted in tradition and paying homage to the generations of the family who farmed this land before. Arnaud is the future, experimenting, re-evaluating, and driving the wines to newfound heights – even chosen by Wine Enthusiast as one of the "Champagne Producers Redefining France’s Bubbly." Combined, they are the perfect complement to one another – mad scientist and wizened sage – ever evolving without getting too far off track. We’ve certainly noticed an uptick in their overall quality over the past few years and this beauty just might be one of their best yet!

A blend of 85% pinot noir and 15% chardonnay from Les Riceys, located in the Côte des Bar, the heart of Champagne. These vines are grown in the region’s mix of clay and chalk soils amongst the rolling wood-topped hills surrounding their village...an area well-suited to pinot noir. The wine is matured in a combination of oak barrels and four egg-shaped clay amphorae the family imported from Tuscany. After spending 7 years on the lees, the wine is disgorged in the “à la volée” style, wherein the yeast is forcefully expelled without first freezing the neck of the bottle. Quite the sight! The dosage here is 8 grams per liter, and the balance and harmony provided are pristine. It’s utterly delicious, compelling stuff that is laser-focused and bubbling with apricot marmalade, pie crust, white flowers, poached pear, and lemon curd...MMMM!! Rich and weighty on the palate, this has a slight caramel finish to complement the baked apple, citrus, and toasty layers.

Yes, Arnaud Gallimard is a certified rockstar. At a sparkling over 45% OFF, this is a bubble for stocking you up through the holidays and beyond...while it lasts, of course!
summary: Didier Gallimard is the sixth generation grower producer who owns 25 acres in the Aube region of Champagne. The heavier clay soils and the slightly warmer climate produces wines of a richer style. They specialize in pinot noir which is sourced from Les Riceys. We got to visit this amazing winery during Prowein and one of our most fondest memories was visiting their vineyards. It was so picturesque with views of the Frech countryside that extended for miles.

title: Albino Rocca Barbaresco Ronchi 2019
summary: "Our history starts in the mid 1940’s when Albino Rocca’s father Giacomo started in the wine business initially selling grapes from family vineyards and later making his own wine that was sold in demijohn. Thanks to the inheritance of some of our most precious vineyards in the 1960’s our grandfather was able to start what is now our winery Albino Rocca. Albino’s hard work and his strong support of our father Angelo Rocca laid the foundation that created a family winemaking tradition that has grown internationally over the years. Our history has been built together, year by year. First through the gradual acquisition of vineyards and the production of not only Nebbiolo, but also Dolcetto and Barbera in addition to our continuous effort to evolve the quality of our Barbaresco – which starts in the vineyards and continues in the cellar."

title: Joseph Phelps Backus Vineyard Napa Valley 1997
summary: Joseph Phelps Vineyards is a family-owned and operated wine estate with vineyards and wineries in Napa Valley and on the western Sonoma Coast. The winery was founded in 1973 by Joseph Phelps, a successful construction executive and entrepreneur whose early interest in wine led him to establish vineyards on a 670-acre former cattle ranch in Napa Valley. Over the next 42 years Joe became one of the most respected figures in the California wine industry, building Joseph Phelps Vineyards into a critically-acclaimed winery internationally known for its iconic wines and unwavering commitment to quality. Joseph most notably created the first ever "fanciful name" for his flagship wine Insignia, which had a dramatic effect on the way wine was marketed around the world to this day.

title: Corra Cabernet Sauvignon Napa Valley 2007 (slightly stained label)
summary:
Celia Welch, consulting winemaker to some of Napa Valley’s finest Cabernet Sauvignon estates, is proud to welcome you to her own endeavor, CORRA.

Grapes from three prime vineyards in three of Napa Valley’s premium growing regions, Oakville, Rutherford and Pritchard Hill, combine to create the powerful yet elegant Corra Cabernet Sauvignon.

Corra, a Celtic deity representing prophecy, symbolizes this small brand’s forward-looking perspective. Showing herself on earth in the form of a crane, Corra takes wing and lifts her shadow to life.

summary: Four generations of the Mondavi family have grown and produced wines among the world's finest. Cesare Mondavi was the first to bring wine to the table but it was his son Robert's passion for excellence, which inspired both his family and the world. Tim and Marcia Mondavi, along with their children, maintain this continuum of excellence, innovation, and tradition at their estate, high on Pritchard Hill.

title: Kongsgaard Chardonnay Judge Napa Valley 2002
summary: "Fifth-generation Napa natives, Maggy and I began our endeavor in the 1970s planting The Judge vineyard on the Kongsgaard family land near Napa. The inaugural Kongsgaard wines came in 1996. We now produce The Judge, Chardonnay, Cabernet Sauvignon, Syrah, Viognier, Sauvignon Blanc and Albarino in our underground winery, a cave dug into the volcanic rock, high on the eastern rim of the Napa Valley where we have planted a spectacular mountain vineyard. We also direct the farming under long-term contracts on several perfect acres in the Napa Carneros and near the winery. These intensely farmed, shy-bearing vineyards and our traditional low-intervention winemaking produce powerful, graceful wines - vivid expressions of vineyard and variety. Production is limited to what we, with our son Alex, can make with our own hands." - John Kongsgaard

title: Kosta Browne Chardonnay One Sixteen 2012 (slightly stained label)
summary: Truly great wines are born in the vineyard. Over the years, Kosta Browne made it their business to find incredible growers and vineyards in key appellations throughout California. Every vintage a story is told of these chosen vineyards through the medium of wine. Their efforts reflect the character in some way, of every person and every vineyard site; the shared experiences of that year. Kosta Browne's appellation blends are inspired by a desire to capture the specific beauty of each of these growing regions. Kosta Browne produces three appellation Pinot Noirs - Russian River Valley, Sonoma Coast and Santa Lucia Highlands, and one Chardonnay from the Russian River Valley.

title: Kapcsandy Cabernet Sauvignon Grand Vin State Lane Vineyard 2017
summary: Lou Kapcsandy (pronounced "Cup-chon-dy") came to the US from his native Hungary in 1956, pursuing a successful career in chemical engineering and manufacturing. Through collleagues in the wine industry, the wine bug grew. In 1998, Lou and his wife, Bobbie, visited Leoville-Las-Cases and they were smitten by the idea of opening up their own winery back in the states. The Kapcsandys purchased the historic Beringer Estate State Lane vineyard (which was home to that company's Private Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon program). They have since then replanted the vineyards primarily to Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot, Cabernet Franc, and Petit Verdot and a new winery was built in 2005. They have a family mentality of producing consistent "First Growth" quality wines that rival the best wine regions of the world.

title: Senses Cabernet Sauvignon Oakville 2016
summary:
Senses Wines is the dream of three childhood friends. Chris, Max and Myles partnered with critically acclaimed winemaker, Thomas Rivers Brown, to produce world-class wines from renowned vineyards owned by their families. Since founding in 2011, Senses production has grown to include many coveted vineyard sites throughout northern California.

The Senses estate vineyards are located in the West Sonoma Coast region of Sonoma County, specifically in the small town of Occidental where the three founders grew up.

title: Cattleya Syrah The Initiation 2018
summary: Bibiana Gonzalez Rave is the founder and winemaker of Cattleya Wines. Born and raised in Colombia and trained as a winemaker in France, she moved to California in 2007. She had always dreamt of making wine since she was a teenager. She trained herself while working with some amazing winemakers who showed her the importance of loving the land, how to respect the farming, and to focus on the many details that go into making each bottle. Making the highly acclaimed wines of Pahlmeyer and Wayfarer over the last several years inspired her to go out on her own and the results are extraordinary. You heard it here folks, this is a producer you want to know!

title: Kongsgaard Grenache Syrah Napa Valley 2006
summary: "Fifth-generation Napa natives, Maggy and I began our endeavor in the 1970s planting The Judge vineyard on the Kongsgaard family land near Napa. The inaugural Kongsgaard wines came in 1996. We now produce The Judge, Chardonnay, Cabernet Sauvignon, Syrah, Viognier, Sauvignon Blanc and Albarino in our underground winery, a cave dug into the volcanic rock, high on the eastern rim of the Napa Valley where we have planted a spectacular mountain vineyard. We also direct the farming under long-term contracts on several perfect acres in the Napa Carneros and near the winery. These intensely farmed, shy-bearing vineyards and our traditional low-intervention winemaking produce powerful, graceful wines - vivid expressions of vineyard and variety. Production is limited to what we, with our son Alex, can make with our own hands." - John Kongsgaard

title: Shared Notes Sauvignon Blanc-Semillon Les Lecons de Maitres 2018
summary: Shared Notes is the winemaking joint-venture between wife and husband, Bibiana Gonzalez Rave and Jeff Pisoni. Both had early desires of making wine, and spent most of their lives doing so. The year 2012, however, marked the first vintage that they produced together.

title: Domaine Audebert & Fils Bourgueil Les Marquises 2015
description:
Ah, Bourgueil! Cabernet franc may be a blending grape in Bordeaux and most other regions around the world, but here, in the heart of the Loire, cabernet franc is KING! The Audebert family, a Kermit Lynch find from decades past, is one of our favorite franc producers and this parcel from their 60-year-old vines is just mind-shatteringly wicked good juice. Normally $50, but here at First Bottle, we waived the magical wine wand to bring it to you for only $29.95!!!

Yep, that’s a solid 40% OFF on some of the most highly-sought Loire cabernet franc in the world. Sommeliers have been gobbling this up for years, and not just for the obvious quality, the unbelievable food friendliness, and the fascinating history, either… this wine is built to last! Similar to how the wine world recently learned that cru Beaujolais is one of the best aging dry red wines in the world, Bourgueil cabernet franc (locally dubbed cabernet breton) has the distinct capability to age for decades!

This 1.5-hectare site, where 60-year-old vines dominate, is set amongst a rich, clay, and limestone soil in the commune of Benais. The vineyard is known for producing the most powerfully structured wines in the Audebert portfolio, and vintages from three decades past are still drinking well today. Aging is not required, however, as the pure bright fruit notes, the red floral overtones, and the supple and spicy earth notes are all there to be enjoyed, even in its “youth” (at seven years young already, many lesser Loire cabernet francs would be nearing the end of their life and not the beginning of maturity as this one is here!).

This remarkable wine is highly perfumed with hibiscus flowers, dried violets, and cranberry tea, followed by deeply flavored notes of fresh-made berry jam, cardamom, burdock root, clove, and cool spearmint. The finish is long, intense, and spicy, with notes of iron ore and smoked meats. Unbelievably complex and primordially satisfying, this is a cabernet franc that bridges the void between your prototypical Chinons and the rich, lush cabernet francs from Bolgheri, Napa, and Bordeaux’s Right Bank. For $29.95?!?! Don’t miss this!!!
summary: The Audebert family settled in the Bourgueil area in 1839 and now own and farm almost 100 acres of vineyard in Bourgueil, Saint Nicolas de Bourgueil and Chinon appellations. Breton specialists, the local term for Cabernet Franc, the Audeberts were discovered by Kermit Lynch who first brought them stardom in the states with sommeliers. Their vines in Bourgueil are planted on a mixture of clay, sand and limestone with an average vine age of 26 years.

title: Guigal Cote Rotie Chateau d'Ampuis 2018
description:
Ah, Guigal. Côte-Rôtie. Does it get any better? Jeb Dunnuck calls this “one of the world’s greatest wine estates for over seven decades,” and we fully agree. 95+, 96, and 97-99 scores attest to what we expected one sip in...this is one of the best Château d'Ampuis wines ever! And a BONUS deal of over $60 OFF on a 6-pack, Huzzah! Super-limited, but not to be missed!

What can we say, Guigal is just so very close to our hearts. Like so many, Marcel’s wines may have been your Côte-Rôtie epiphany back in the day, or perhaps one waiting to happen. Trust us, they have never been better. Just read the reviews below. We particularly love Dunnuck’s assertion that Guigal’s Ampuis falls “certainly in the same league as the famed La Las...” – meaning, of course, La Mouline, La Turque, and La Landonne (all falling at ~$400 each). If that quip doesn’t grab your attention...check your pulse.

Château d'Ampuis is a blend of their top seven estate vineyards in Côte-Rôtie, including the La Garde, Le Clos, Grande-Plantée, Pommière, Pavillon, Le Moulin, and La Viria lieux-dits. It sees prolonged aging of nearly four full years in new French oak and is handled exactly like the single vineyard “La Las” releases with a four-week maceration and fermentation prior to pressing. Ampuis is composed of 93% syrah and 7% viognier and is about as classic a Côte-Rôtie as you’ll ever taste. Powerfully aromatic notes of smoke, spice, and floral, bound together with deep bramble berries of black and blue, followed by earthy and oak-driven notes of black pepper and espresso...this is tremendously hedonistic, and yet dramatically elegant and silky. Perfect with a decant now, better still in a couple years!

This Château d'Ampuis is a personal favorite because, while at the level of the legendary La Las, especially in a great vintage like 2018, this is so much more approachable to your wallet. Incredible bang for the buck, yet with all of the power, the intensity, and the ageability, just immense.

The Guigal family spent 15 years restoring Château d'Ampuis, a historic property whose oldest sections date to the 11th century. The Chateau d’Ampuis has been the symbol of the town of Ampuis and the world-renowned Côte-Rôtie vineyard area for ten centuries. These seven exceptional vineyards from both sides of Cote-Rotie, three on the Côte Blonde and four on the Côte Brune, are further distinguished in that each vineyard adjoins one of the three Guigal single vineyard crus of La Mouline, La Landonne, or La Turque. That makes it all part of some of the greatest places to grow syrah anywhere in the world, and this lives up to every drop of hype! Secure as much as you can, you will not be sorry!
summary: The Guigal domain was founded in 1946 by Etienne Guigal in the ancient village of Ampuis, home of the wines of the Côte-Rôtie. Etienne Guigal arrived in this region in 1923 at the age of 14. He made wine for over 67 vintages and, at the beginning of his career, participated in the development of the Vidal-Fleury establishment. Despite his young age, Marcel Guigal took over from his father in 1961 when the latter was victim to a brutal illness rendering him blind. Marcel's hard work and perseverance enabled the Guigals to buy out Vidal-Fleury in 1984, although the establishment retains its own identity and commercial autonomy. In 2000, the Guigals purchased the Jean-Louis Grippat estate in Saint-Joseph and Hermitage, as well as the Domaine de Vallouit in Côte-Rôtie, Hermitage, Saint-Joseph and Crozes-Hermitage. Produced from seven of the most exceptional plots of the domain, Château d’Ampuis is a classy wine with toasty aromas of black fruit. Its tannic structure and elegance contribute to its ageing potential.

title: Nikolaihof Gelber Muskateller Trocken 2020
description: A 2,000 year old estate that dates back to the Roman Empire, has been farmed without the use of chemicals since 470 AD, and a bio-dynamic pioneer since 1971?!? That’s Nikolaihof. Owned and operated by the Saahs family since the late 1800s, this remarkable estate is the jewel of the Wachau. While they make plenty of world class rieslings and grüner veltliners, this is a dry muscat – and the perfect introduction to this estate. Delightfully aromatic, mouth coating and watering, this is crisp, focused, and mineral-driven in a structured manner not typically seen in the varietal. Grown on river gravel and loess from the nearby Danube, this wine takes a serious twist on a normally playful grape. Flavors and aromas of apricot, fresh herbs, pomelo, and crushed rocks carry the day, with structure to last a decade! Cool stuff and not to be missed!
summary: With almost 2,000 years of history, Nikolaihof is the oldest winery in Austria and one of the first in the world to have begun working by biodynamic principles. The grapes are harvested by hand, fermented without artificial yeast and stored in big, old Austrian oak casks. Nikolaihof is one of the most exciting wineries in the Wachau today, ask any serious sommelier his or her shortlist of the best of Austria and Nikolaihof will be on there. It was, at various times, a celtic place of worship, part of a Roman fort, a bishop's seat and an administrative center. History and tradition prevail in these focused, lip-smacking wines.
